intro: Bupleurum gerardi var. subadpressum, commonly known as the narrow-leafed bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, featuring slender, hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often tinged with silver. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers in shades of blue or purple, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade, making it a suitable candidate for rock gardens or alpine settings. Its botanical features make it a valuable addition to both ornamental and ecological landscapes.
